How Einstein Copilot Works

Follow the path of a user request through the copilot platform to learn how a copilot reasons and responds dynamically in a conversation.

REQUIRED EDITIONS
Available in: Lightning Experience
Available in: Enterprise, Performance, and Unlimited Editions with the Einstein for Sales, Einstein for Service, or Einstein Platform add-ons
Step 1: Identifying the user’s intent

The journey begins when a user starts a conversation in the Einstein panel. The user can select from suggested actions, which are dynamic based on the record page. Or the user can enter their own task or question.

In this case, the user enters “Show me a list of my open opportunities”.

The copilot sends a prompt through the Trust Layer to the LLM to identify the user’s intent, or the user’s purpose or goal.

Step 2: Generating a plan

Based on the user’s intent, the planner service builds a plan. Think of a plan as a conversational roadmap that identifies the copilot actions to use to accomplish the user’s goal. A plan can range from one action to a chain of actions.

To generate a plan, the planner service sends a prompt to the LLM. The prompt includes all the actions assigned to the copilot that the user has access to, as well as the user’s conversation history and context. The LLM uses the names and instructions for each copilot action to identify the best matching actions and put them in the right order.

Step 3: Executing the plan

The copilot begins executing the actions in the plan.

In this example, the plan is straightforward: The copilot must execute only the Query Records action. Behind the scenes, the Query Records action executes a standard invocable action to search for records based on the user input. Because this action doesn’t execute a prompt template, the copilot doesn’t even have to make an LLM call.

However, plans can be more complicated. For example, if the user asks the copilot “Summarize the Acme deal,” the copilot executes at least two actions: Identify Record by Name and Summarize Record.

In this case, the Identify Record by Name action is required because the user provided the record name, but the Summarize Record action uses a record ID string. To get the record ID string, the plan tells the copilot to execute the Identify Record by Name system action first.

In this example, the Summarize Record copilot action executes a standard invocable action, which searches for related prompt templates based on the record to summarize—in this case, an opportunity—and user access. The standard invocable action executes a prompt template, which includes relevant data and specifies the content and format of the summary. The prompt is sent to the LLM to generate the summary.

Step 4: Generating a response

The copilot delivers a response to the user. The copilot sends a prompt to the LLM to generate a friendly message and return the output of the action as rich text or structured content.

A LIST OF OPEN OPPORTUNITIES	A SUMMARY OF AN ACCOUNT RECORD

	

If something goes wrong—for example, the copilot can’t understand the request, or it can’t find any matching records—the copilot makes an LLM call to respond with a generated error message.

Step 5: Keeping the conversation going

The conversation doesn’t have to end with one request. Because the copilot understands each interaction in the context of the larger conversation, the user can ask a follow-up question or change the subject entirely, and the copilot responds appropriately.

Behind the scenes, this starts the journey over. But to the user, it feels like they’re naturally taking turns in a conversation.
